node.text:
VIDEO CASE⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
BRAIN METASTASES⁣
👨🏽‍💻This case is all about being able to tell the difference between cytotoxic and vasogenic oedema. Let’s look at each in turn:⁣
⁣
VASOGENIC OEDEMA⁣
▫️blood-brain barrier disrupted⁣
▫️mainly affects white matter giving finger like pattern⁣
▫️seen predominantly with space occupying lesions such as tumour or abscess⁣
⁣
CYTOTOXIC OEDEMA⁣
▫️blood-brain barrier intact⁣
▫️Na+/K+ pumps fail to operate⁣
▫️Na+ accumulation within cells leading to water being drawn in⁣
▫️leads to ionic oedema with extracellular water accumulation seen as low attenuation within both grey and white matter on CT⁣
▫️loss of grey-white matter differentiation on CT⁣
▫️seen with ischaemic stroke⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In this case we can see diffuse low density affecting just the white matter - diffuse vasogenic oedema. This should then alert you to the possibility of space occupying lesions which you just make out without IV contrast. Once we give the contrast we can then see multiple ring enhancing lesions⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Malignancy and infection make up the vast majority of peripherally enhancing brain lesions and diffusion weighted MRI is really helpful in trying to tell the difference between abscess and cancer. Abscesses usually light up on DWI given that pus restricts the movement of water molecules whereas this is less the case with malignancy⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In this case there was a background of breast cancer and the metastases all resolved on giving chemotherapy with remission maintained several years down the line⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
✅Patient consent obtained ⁣
⁣
——-⁣
⁣

⁣
———-⁣

node.text:
VIDEO CASE⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
COVID-19 PNEUMONIA AND SUSPECTED MYOCARDITIS⁣
👨🏽‍💻Chest X-Ray findings can vary - it can be normal in mild cases or early disease but those presenting to hospital will commonly show bilateral peripheral consolidation. This can progress to diffuse consolidation and an ARDS pattern⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻The pattern in this case can be referred to the ‘reverse bat wing’, ie the opposite of the bat wing pattern you see in pulmonary oedema where you get central consolidation ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻What is not common in COVID-19?⁣
▫️Small nodules⁣
▫️Pleural effusions ⁣
▫️Enlarged mediastinal nodes⁣
▫️Cavitating lesions ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Although chest X-Ray can be suggestive remember it is not specific - remember RT-PCR is much more specific (although not completely sensitive). Identical X-rays to this can also be seen in inflammatory conditions such as eosinophilic pneumonia and vasculitis ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Imaging rationales vary across the world - in the UK, the British Society of Thoracic Imaging do not recommend CT as an initial diagnostic tool partly due to problems with exposing the scanner and staff. CXR however does have a role in initial work up ⁣
⁣
▫️Good luck to all healthcare professionals across the world dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣

👍Patient consent obtained

node.text:
VIDEO CASE

PULMONARY OEDEMA/DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY
👨🏽‍💻The initial X-ray has the classic ‘bat wing’ oedema pattern - commonly seen in acute pulmonary oedema. It is worth bearing in mind that there is a differential for this appearance. Remember the presence of consolidation on an X-ray simply means the alveoli are being filled - this can happen in infection, heart failure, pulmonary haemorrhage and lung cancer

👨🏽‍💻It is the pattern of consolidation and the ancillary findings that help us pick these apart on an X-ray. Central bilateral consolidation is commonly seen in acute pulmonary oedema - compare this with COVID where the pattern is more bilateral PERIPERHAL consolidation

👨🏽‍💻In this case we can also see ‘Kerley B lines’ - horizontal thin lines at the lung bases which helps us decide this is pulmonary oedema. Now remember not all pulmonary oedema is cardiogenic, in this case we can go back to a previous CT and see that the left ventricle was dilated making us more sure that this is cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

👨🏽‍💻The most common cause of LV dysfunction worldwide is ischaemic heart disease. The cardiac MRI in this case helps us by excluding ischaemic heart disease as a cause for the dilated LV. With an ischaemic cardiomyopathy we may expect ‘subendocardial’ (ie the inner part of the myocardium) or transmural enhancement on late gadolinium images whereas in this case we have no enhancement

👨🏽‍💻The underlying diagnosis in this case is dilated cardiomyopathy which was deemed idiopathic. Other causes include prior myocarditis, thyrotoxicosis , alcohol and chemotherapy agents

▫️Hopefully this case will help you to recognise acute pulmonary oedema the next time you see it 

🔻@theradiologistpage

node.text:
CHEST X-RAY REVIEW AREAS IN ONE MINUTE⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Check out this one minute video where I show all the review areas I go through every time I look at a Chest X-Ray⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Using a system is so important when it comes to not missing subtle findings that completely change the diagnosis. When training in radiology I found this really difficult to stick to and it’s taken years of practice to have the mental discipline to go through the same routine every time I look at a Chest X-Ray⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Some X-Rays may have an obvious abnormality - in which case I find it best to assess the problem then go through all the review areas to make sure there isn’t a further problem which may change the diagnosis. Don’t get caught out by satisfaction of search!⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻I’m not saying this is the only way to look at a chest X-ray - it’s best for you to make your own system that is personal to you. Hopefully this can give you some ideas on how to create your own system!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
——⁣
#theradiologist #radiology #radiologist #physician #physicianassistant #medicine #medstudent #medicalstudent #medschool #medicalschool #radtech #whitecoat #mri #xray #medical #radiography #radiologystudent #doctor #medicalstudents #interventionalradiology #chestxray #surgeon #medic #frcr #anatomy #usmle #medlife #exams #premed⁣⁣

node.text:
AXIAL LUMBAR SPINE MRI ANATOMY⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Here we have an axial slice of the lumbar spine with T1 weighting - notice how the fluid in the spinal canal is dark ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻When looking at the axial slices I find it helpful to have the sagittal slices along side this to let me know at which level I am at ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Take note of:⁣
▫️The intervertebral or neural foramen - this is an opening on either side of the spine which allows the nerve root to leave the spine. There is usually fat within this which is high signal on T1 and T2 images. Within this you should be able to find the nerve root as a dark structure. Remember the exiting nerve root here will be the same number as the level you’re at - so here we are at L4 so the nerve roots we can see within the foramina are the L4 nerve roots. The L5 nerve roots are about to leave the spinal canal (although can’t be seen well on T1 weighted images here) and enter the lateral recess ⁣
▫️Check the facet joints and ligamentum flavum for hypertrophy. Ligamentum flavum hypetrophy may contribute to spinal canal stenosis whilst facet joint hypertrophy can be a source of back pain and should be commented on in the report ⁣
▫️Don’t forget the structures away from the spine! Check the ureters for dilatation and look at the aorta - you may see an incidental aneurysm. Enlarged lymph nodes in the retroperitoneum can also be picked up incidentally on spine MRI!⁣
⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by theRadiologist on September 01, 2021. May be a cartoon of text that says 'theRadiologist The new junior doctor being sent to radiology to ask for a scan for a patient they ve never seen with a condition they've never heard of'.

node.text:
Have a look at these coronal images from a post contrast CT and then swipe left and read on for the explanation⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
AUTOSOMAL DOMINANT POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE (ADPKD)⁣
👨🏽‍💻The CT shows a large number of simple cysts within both kidneys. Once you see this many cysts you have to consider autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease which is a medical exam favourite⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻 Mutations in the PKD1 (85% of cases) and PKD2 (15%) genes lead to this disease where progressive growth of cysts leads to decline in renal function, meaning many go on to need renal replacement therapy. This is the case here with a transplant kidney within the right iliac fossa. Cysts can also be found in the liver which we can also see⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻There are many things associated with ADPKD including:⁣
▫️cerebral aneurysms⁣
▫️bicuspid aortic valve ⁣
▫️mitral valve prolapse⁣
▫️aortic dissection⁣
▫️hypertension⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Although the chance of a renal cell carcinoma arising in one of these cysts is low, on imaging it is important to look through all cysts, looking for any suspicious lesion with a soft tissue component. With CT, it may be necessary to acquire both non contrast and post contrast images to look for a suspicious enhancing component to a cyst⁣
⁣
@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
———-⁣
⁣

node.text:
PELVIC MRI ANATOMY⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Here’s an annotated coronal image from a male pelvic MRI⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Take a look at:⁣
⁣
▫️the iliac and psoas major muscles which join to form the iliopsoas muscle whose insertion we can see at the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas is key in hip flexion⁣
⁣
▫️the adductor muscles - we can see some of the adductor muscles here, these pull the legs together and help to stabilise the hip joint. They mainly insert on the medial surface of the femur ⁣
⁣
▫️two of the gluteal muscles which originate at the ilium and insert onto the femur. The larger gluteus maximus muscle is more posterior to this level⁣
⁣
▫️vastus lateralis - which makes up part of the quadriceps femoris within the thigh⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
——-⁣
 ⁣
#theradiologist #radiology #radiologist #physician #physicianassistant #medicine #medstudent #medicalstudent #medschool #medicalschool #radtech #whitecoat #mri #xray #medical #radiography #radiologystudent #doctor #medicalstudents #interventionalradiology #surgeon #medic #frcr #anatomy #neurology #usmle #medlife #exams #premed⁣

node.text:
Improve your knowledge of brain imaging with this MRI FLAIR sequence image at the level of the basal ganglia and thalami ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻I found the basal ganglia anatomy difficult when first starting radiology but getting a good grasp really helps in assessing scans and understanding pathology ⁣
⁣
WHAT IS THE BASAL GANGLIA?⁣
👨🏽‍💻The basal ganglia are a group of structures that are important in motor function, facilitating movement and inhibiting competing movements ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻By far the most common pathology I see affecting the basal ganglia and thalamus is ischaemic stroke ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Picking up stroke on CT in the very acute setting is difficult - the value of acute CT is to rule out haemorrhage which may present similarly prior to starting antiplatelets or thrombolysing⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻MRI is far more sensitive for acute ischaemic stroke thanks to diffusion weighted imaging (DWI). This looks at how much water molecules diffuse - in acute stroke the water molecules are restricted and we’ll see a DWI sequence light up in the affected area ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Other pathologies can affect the basal ganglia although are less common. You can split these up into whether they are:⁣
⁣
BILATERAL SYMMETRICAL⁣
▫️Metabolic causes (eg Wernicke)⁣
▫️Toxins such as carbon monoxide⁣
▫️Degenerative (eg CJD)⁣
⁣
UNILATERAL⁣
▫️Ischaemia - can be bilateral, can be venous infarction - consider this when coexistent haemorrhage⁣
▫️Infection⁣
▫️Neoplasm⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage

node.text:
Have a look at this X-Ray and swipe left and read on for the explanation ⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
OPACITY BEHIND THE HEART⁣
👨🏽‍💻This is a really subtle finding but at the same time a really important one. Not looking in the retrocardiac region and comparing right to left can mean the difference between picking up a life changing lung cancer and missing it....which can mean delayed diagnosis and preventing life changing treatment. So this is an important review area!⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻How do we assess this region? I first check the film is adequately exposed by looking to see if I can make out the vertebrae behind the heart. If I can make out the end-plates then I’m safe to make a fair assessment. You may need to use your PACS system to window the film. I then compare the right and left side looking to check I can see lung markings, with the density being roughly the same⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In this case the right side is more dense than the left side - once you see a discrepancy like this you really need a good reason why! There’s a variety of causes (detailed in the post) but one of the most important is a lung cancer⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻The next step is to check the lateral film (if you have one) or assess further on CT - there are differing practices over the world for this step. In this case the patient has a mass behind the heart which was confirmed on biopsy as a primary lung cancer⁣
⁣
🔻The finding on this film is subtle but the reason I’m sharing it is to make you think again the next time you look at a chest X-Ray - if you look at enough films you’ll almost certainly run into an abnormality in the retrocardiac region!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
——⁣

node.text:
Read on for my tips at looking at a sagittal view MRI of the brain ⁣
⁣
T1 WEIGHTED SAGITTAL MRI BRAIN⁣
👨🏽‍💻I always like to review a sagittal view of the brain on MRI and CT as it shows us some things that aren’t as evident on an axial view. I always make sure to check...⁣
⁣
▫️PITUITARY: check the pituitary gland isn’t enlarged. On a T1 sequence the posterior pituitary is seen as a bright spot - if this is lost consider infiltration by tumour or an ectopic posterior pituitary⁣
⁣
▫️TECTUM/PINEAL GLAND: I always check this region for an incidental tumour, I have seen cases where this hasn’t been apparent on an axial image but reveals itself on a sagittal!⁣
⁣
▫️TENTORIUM: the sagittal view is great for checking the tentorium for subdural blood or dural metastatic disease on post contrast images which is typical in breast cancer (in the latter look for areas of nodular enhancement)⁣
⁣
▫️CEREBELLAR TONSILS: check these have not herniated below the foramen magnum. In acute hydrocephalus this can occur due to mass effect. Otherwise significantly herniated tonsils are seen in Arnold Chiari malformations - if you see this check the cord on T2 images for a syrinx (ie a fluid cavity)⁣
⁣
▫️C-SPINE: the sagittal view gives you a great view of the upper C-spine!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage

node.text:
Have a look at the X-ray then swipe left and read on for the explanation...⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
BRONCHIECTASIS⁣
👨🏽‍💻This is a subtle one but adjacent to the right heart border there are ‘ring shadows’ which bring up the possibility of bronchiectasis⁣
⁣
WHAT IS BRONCHIECTASIS?⁣
👨🏽‍💻This refers to abnormal dilatation of the airways and the causes include:⁣
▫️IDIOPATHIC⁣
▫️POST INFECTION: common cause in adults⁣
▫️CYSTIC FIBROSIS: common cause in children. On CT look for upper lobe involvement classically and assess the pancreas for fatty replacement⁣
▫️ABPA (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis): consider in asthmatics. On CT you may see areas of consolidation and bronchoceles, some of which are high density⁣
▫️TRACTION BRONCHIECTASIS: occurs as a part of fibrosis, usually a sign of irreversible damage in chronic lung fibrosis⁣
▫️ UNCOMMON CAUSES: primary immunodeficiency disorders, primary ciliary dyskinesia, yellow nail syndrome⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻On CT it is really important to assess the airways systematically. With bronchiectasis we are looking for an increase in ‘bronchoarterial ratio’ of more than 1, ie the airway is larger than the corresponding pulmonary artery. This can give you an appearance of something called the ‘signet ring sign’⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻As well as airway dilatation, when looking at the bronchi also look for signs of airway inflammation ie bronchial wall thickening and mucus plugging⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻We can divide the morphology of bronchiectasis into three types which can be considered a spectrum of severity, with the three commonly co-existing:⁣
1️⃣CYLINDRICAL: uniform diameter, most common⁣
2️⃣VARICOSE: beaded appearance, less common⁣
3️⃣CYSTIC: cystic appearance⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Cystic bronchiectasis can be tricky to differentiate from cystic lung disease or the honeycombing we see with lung fibrosis. Useful tips are that cystic bronchiectasis tends to cluster together with an appearance like a bunch of grapes like we can see on the CT in this case. Also connecting the cysts to the airways tells you that you are dealing with cystic bronchiectasis⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
———⁣

node.text:
What arteries supply the upper limb? Let’s take a look...⁣
⁣
UPPER LIMB ARTERIAL ANATOMY⁣
⁣
The main 5 arteries are:⁣
1️⃣ Subclavian artery⁣
▫️We start off above the arm with the subclavian artery - this arises from the brachiocephalic trunk on the right whilst on the left it usually arises directly from the aortic arch (remember the usual three main branches of the arch of the aorta are the brachiocephalic trunk, the left common carotid artery and the left subclavian artery)⁣
⁣
▫️It courses laterally towards the arm becoming the axillary artery at the lateral border of the first rib⁣
⁣
2️⃣ Axillary artery⁣
▫️This runs underneath pectoralis minor, becoming the brachial artery at the lower border of teres minor ⁣
⁣
3️⃣ Brachial artery⁣
▫️The vessel then passes into the cubital fossa where it divides into the: ⁣
⁣
4️⃣ Radial artery ⁣
▫️Supplying the posterolateral part of the forearm⁣
And⁣
5️⃣ Ulna artery ⁣
▫️Supplying the anteromedial part of the foreman ⁣
⁣
▫️The radial and ulnar arteries then anastomose with each other, forming two palmar arches supplying the hand - the superficial and deep palmar arches ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Before looking at scans it’s so important to have a good grasp of the basic anatomy so any time spent reviewing this is in my opinion time well spent!⁣
⁣
@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
⁣
————⁣
